pageTitle: 1958 CHEVROLET BEL AIR Information Specifications Resources Pictures
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {893=Chevrolet's 1958 lineup featured one year only styling that sported "curves where before there were lines." The Bel Air lineup continued to be a success for Chevrolet and in 1958, models ranged from two door sedans to station wagons.  New to the Bel Air line was the well-appointed Impala models available as either a 2-door hardtop coupe or 2-door convertible.  Once again, the Nomad Station wagon was available but this time as a four door station wagon. Also new was a 348 cubic inch V8 big block engine which was originally intended for Chevrolet Trucks.  Among that, customers had 6 other great V8’s and fuel saving 6-cylinders to choose from.}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {4808=Note: After 1957, Chevrolet did not provide breakdown by individual model series, only body style. Production numbers were, four-door sedan = 491,441; two-door sedan = 256,182; four-door station wagon = 170,473; sport coupe = 142,592; sport sedan = 83,330; convertible = 55,989; two-door station wagon = 16,590., 26484=*Overdrive distinguished from 3-Speed by physical appearance only. The above transmissions will carry a production code number such as: S304 (S = Saginaw 3-Speed, 3 = March, 04 = 4th.)}
textBeforeTable: 1958 Chevrolet Bel Air Production Numbers         Chevrolet's 1958 lineup featured one year only styling that sported "curves where before there were lines." The Bel Air lineup continued to be a success for Chevrolet and in 1958, models ranged from two door sedans to station wagons.  New to the Bel Air line was the well-appointed Impala models available as either a 2-door hardtop coupe or 2-door convertible.  Once again, the Nomad Station wagon was available but this time as a four door station wagon. Also new was a 348 cubic inch V8 big block engine which was originally intended for Chevrolet Trucks.  Among that, customers had 6 other great V8’s and fuel saving 6-cylinders to choose from. 1958 Bel Air document.write(''); if(typeof(tile) == "undefined"){var tile = 1} else {tile++} if(typeof(dcopt) == "undefined"){var dcopt = "dcopt=ist;"} else {var dcopt = ""} if(typeof(cachebuster) == "undefined"){var cachebuster = Math.floor(Math.random()*10000000000)}
textAfterTable: See Note Bel Air Series 1800 - V8 F 1849 4 dr Sedan - 6P $2,547 3,470 lbs See Note F 1839 4 dr Hardtop Sport Sedan - 6P $2,618 3,514 lbs See Note F 1841 2 dr Sedan - 6P $2,493 3,427 lbs See Note F 1831 2 dr Hardtop Sport Coupe - 6P $2,554 3,458 lbs See Note F 1847 (IMPALA) 2 dr Hardtop Sport Coupe - 5P $2,693 3,459 lbs See Note F 1867 (IMPALA) 2 dr Hardtop Sport Convertible - 5P $2,841 3,523 lbs See Note F 1893SD 4 dr Nomad - 6P $2,835 3,771 lbs See Note Note: After 1957, Chevrolet did not provide breakdown by individual model series, only body style. Production numbers were, four-door sedan = 491,441; two-door sedan = 256,182; four-door station wagon = 170,473; sport coupe = 142,592; sport sedan = 83,330; convertible = 55,989; two-door station wagon = 16,590. VIN Numbers Serial Numbers were stamped on a plate on the left front door hinge pillar (center pillar on Corvair and on the driver-side door post on Corvette). The Fisher Body number plate on the right-hand side of the cowl gives additional information such as the body style number, the production sequence number, the trim (upholstery) number code and the paint number code.
